messages: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:50): Dammit, Firefox is broken on my system now. Wtf.  From a fresh boot, I try to open it and immediately get the "Firefox is already running" message.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:50): This bothers me because making gradient diagrams is way easier in FF, since they actually implement the syntax.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (18:51): $ killall firefox-bin
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:51): "firefox-bin: no process found"
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:51): Do not try that if you're running Firefox on Solaris.  :)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:52): $ ps aux | grep firefox
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (18:52): I'm assuming Tab is sane
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:52): Be careful what you assume.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:52): Especially in this channel.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (18:52): Well, sane enough not to use solaris
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:52): I mean, maybe he was just heeding the topic.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:52): I have no idea what the implications of anything on Solaris are, as I've never run it.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:53): "killall" on Solaris means "kill all processes".
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:53): On Linux it means "kill all processes with the given name".
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:53): Hilarity ensues.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:53): wouldn't know this stuff, but the Wikimedia toolserver runs almost all Solaris because River Tarnell likes Solaris, and I'm a toolserver root

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:54): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, so it must be checking for a lock file or something, right?  Try "strace firefox 2>&1 | grep 'open('" and see what files it's trying to open.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:54): (Or you could, like, ask one of the several Mozilla developers here instead of listening to me, but then I'd have nothing to say)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:55): The only thing that seems useful is the very last call, where it does 'open("/usr/lib/firefox-3.6.12/firefox", O_RDONLY) = 3
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:56): Surely the lock file (or whatever) is per-user, so /usr/lib seems unlikely.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:56): Also, what kind of weird distro are you using that puts stuff in /usr/lib/firefox-3.6.12?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:56): Goobuntu default.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:56): Oh, looks like Ubuntu does that too.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:57): I wonder why it's not just /usr/lib/firefox/.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:57): Anyway, I'm using the Firefox 4 beta instead.  It's much nicer, maybe you should just switch to that.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:57): (although maybe you'll get the same error)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:57): goes to do that.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:59): Dammit, same problem.
8f450df0506449e82ef31890c3948bbf (18:59): rm ~/.mozilla/firefox/********.Default/lock or something like that
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:59): It's got to be something in your profile.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (18:59): Why doesn't Firefox check whether anything else actually has the lock file open, and ignore it if not?  Or something like that?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:00): Silly Firefox.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:00): (presumably it does and this is something more subtle)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:00): 8f450df0506449e82ef31890c3948bbf: Killed the lock, tried again, no go.
8f450df0506449e82ef31890c3948bbf (19:00): I haven't had lock file problems for years. Used to be a common issue with netscape
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:00): Nuke it from orbit.  It's the only way to be sure.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:01): FIRES ZE MISSILES.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:02): Ah, hrm.  An attempt to rm -rf the .mozilla folder is dying with two files that can't be removed because "Device or resource busy".
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:03): What does that even mean on Unix?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:03): I don't know.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:03): Also, you could have just moved it to .mozilla-old.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:03): Too late now!
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:04): You probably need "strace -f", since firefox is just a wrapper script
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:04): Interesting observation.
8c2b4111f14335e65753441e04075f2e (19:04): i think the binary is called firefox-bin
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:05): Well, I knew that, but I didn't know how strace worked.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:05): I just blindly run it on random commands without actually understanding what I'm doing.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:05): Um.  Firefox works now?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:05): The beta, at least.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:05): (like, I have no idea if grepping for "open" made any sense here, maybe it would be getting file descriptors through some other syscall, I dunno)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:06): Anyway, I apparently killed *something* useful, because I'm no longer being blocked.  Yay!
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:07): lsof is useful if you want to see what's got a particular file open/locked/etc
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:07): No clue where this thing is trying to store my profile now, though.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:08): It didn't recreate the directory?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:09): Oh, there it is got it.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:13): Thanks, everyone.  High fives all around.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:14): Thanks for helping you decide to fix a Firefox problem by just deleting your .mozilla directory since none of us had any idea what was causing the problem, and none of us actually directly suggested the solution of deleting the directory anyway?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:15): Well, you're welcome, then.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:15): Dude, you said "nuke it from orbit".  I don't know how to interpret that other than "rm -rf the fucker".
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:17): Well, yeah, I guess so.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:17): I wasn't really serious, though.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:19): Ah well, I was certain I could repair the damage if I did something wrong, so I rolled with it.
8c2b4111f14335e65753441e04075f2e (19:27): you know you're speaking to geeks when they do a full post mortem of getting firefox to work again :P
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:51): Ah, abusing gradients to make diagonal lines for my diagram is fun.
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:52): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: same to you and more of it :)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:52): It's SVG's fault for being an XML language.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:56): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: Do you have "SVG" in your nicknames file or something?
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:57): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: colloquy lets you set up alert rules
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:58): Yeah, that's what I was wondering.  You seem to show up magically when SVG is mentioned.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:58): "We are about to start implementing stream.record() and StreamRecorder."
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:58): did someone mention SVG?
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (20:00): ah, that explains it :P
